Background.text:
Also known as a Mobitz I or Wenkebach AV block
Disturbance of atrial impulse conducting through the AV node
Considered more benign than Mobitz II as it is not associated with histological changes

Clinical_Features.text:
Usually asymptomatic
Those who are symptomatic may present with:
Lightheadedness/dizziness
Presyncope or
syncope

AV_blocks.text:
First degree AV block
Second degree
Second degree AV block type I
(Wenkebach)
Second degree AV block type II
Third degree AV block
AV dissociation without complete heart block

links.text: Second degree AV block type II

AV_blocks.text:
First degree AV block
Second degree
Second degree AV block type I
(Wenkebach)
Second degree AV block type II
Third degree AV block
AV dissociation without complete heart block

links.text: Second degree AV block type II

Diagnosis.text:
ECG
with:
Progressive prolongation of PR interval on consecutive beats
Dropped QRS beat not conducted to ventricle after maximal PR prolongation
After dropped QRS complex, PR interval resets and again begins the cycle of progressive prolongation

ECG
with:
Progressive prolongation of PR interval on consecutive beats
Dropped QRS beat not conducted to ventricle after maximal PR prolongation
After dropped QRS complex, PR interval resets and again begins the cycle of progressive prolongation

ECG
with:
Progressive prolongation of PR interval on consecutive beats
Dropped QRS beat not conducted to ventricle after maximal PR prolongation
After dropped QRS complex, PR interval resets and again begins the cycle of progressive prolongation

Management.text:
Generally benign condition that does not require management after ruling out
MI
,
drug toxicity
,
electrolyte imbalance
and other unusual causes
Symptomatic patients can be treated with
atropine
or
isoproterenol
to transiently improve conduction or with transcutaneous or transvenous pacing if there is associated hypotension
[1]

Disposition.text:
Generally outpatient
2:1 block
[2]
May be unable to determine if Type I or Type II
If so, assume
type II
and admit with cardiology consult
